Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, this Court may modify any prior custody or parenting order when a material and substantial change has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment and such modification promotes the best interests of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A parent’s relocation and the subsequent logistics related to parenting time are recognized as material changes in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context, and applies a best-interests standard. It does not frame relocation or related parenting-time logistics as a “material change in circumstances” or address the threshold for modification based on changed circumstances. Instead, it assumes the case is properly before the court and analyzes whether removal is in the children’s best interests, so it does not support the specific proposition about material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]….”

[The court quotes this ALI principle but does not adopt it as Massachusetts law regarding material change in circumstances.]

Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.raw_text: Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326 (2007)
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.proposition: A parent’s relocation and the subsequent logistics related to parenting time are recognized as material changes in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision and assumes a post‑divorce parenting schedule is already in place; it does not frame the relocation or logistical changes as a “material change in circumstances” justifying modification. The court analyzes the request under the Yannas/Mason/Pizzino ‘real advantage/best interests’ framework, not the threshold standard for modification of custody or parenting time. As a result, it does not clearly stand for the proposition that relocation and related logistics are, in themselves, recognized as a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.relevant_excerpt:
The father filed a counterclaim for modification seeking physical custody of both children and an award of child support from the mother. After a three-day trial... the judge dismissed the mother’s complaint; denied the father’s complaint as to physical custody of the son; amended the divorce judgment by awarding physical custody of the daughter to the father....

In cases such as the one before us, the “real advantage” test applies. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 705, 706, 711 (1985)... Under the real advantage test, “[s]hould it be found that there is a genuine, recognizable advantage to the custodial parent from the move, the inquiry then turns to whether the move is consistent with the children’s best interests.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider the child’s emotional, developmental, and educational needs.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly articulates what factors are relevant to determining the child’s best interests in a removal case, including how the move will affect the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs and the child’s quality and style of life (which encompasses educational opportunities). This aligns with the proposition that courts consider emotional, developmental, and educational needs when assessing a child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, courts consider the child’s emotional, developmental, and educational needs.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.support_reasoning: The court explicitly articulates what factors must be weighed in a best-interests determination and ties them to the child’s particular needs and circumstances. While it does not list ‘educational’ needs by name, it refers broadly to ‘all relevant factors’ and ‘the particular needs and circumstances of the child,’ and cites the governing statute directing consideration of the child’s physical, mental, moral, or emotional health—encompassing emotional and developmental needs. This opinion thus supports the general proposition that courts assess a child’s emotional and developmental needs as part of best-interests analysis, and implicitly educational needs within those broader factors.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488, 495 (2012.relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question. … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.”

Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).proposition: The exhaustion and disruption caused by long midweek commutes directly undermine Emily’s ability to succeed in school and maintain a healthy routine, warranting modification under the principles established in Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997) and Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).support_reasoning: Kendall v. Kendall concerns restrictions on a parent’s ability to expose children to religious teachings when there is clear evidence of substantial emotional harm and decline in academic performance from religious conflict. It does not address physical or logistical harms such as long midweek commutes, school exhaustion, or disruption of daily routines as a basis for modifying custody or parenting-time orders. While the case applies a general ‘best interests/ substantial harm’ framework, it is about religious indoctrination and emotional harm, not commute-related school difficulties, so citing it as establishing principles about long commutes is inaccurate.
Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “The determinative issue is whether the harm found to exist in this case is demonstrated to be so substantial so as to warrant a limitation on the defendant’s religious freedom. In Felton v. Felton, this court suggested that a ‘likely source[]’ of proof of substantial harm ‘by implication’ could be derived from testimony as to the child’s general demeanor, attitude, school work, appetite, health or outlook.… Applying that standard to the facts of this particular case, I see substantial evidence of current and imminent harm, to these 7, 5, and 3-year-old children.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: The exhaustion and disruption caused by long midweek commutes directly undermine Emily’s ability to succeed in school and maintain a healthy routine, warranting modification under the principles established in Kendall v. Kendall, 426 Mass. 238 (1997) and Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: Smith v. McDonald is about statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and relocation rights of an unmarried, sole legal parent prior to an adjudication of paternity. It does not address school performance, midweek commuting burdens, or modification of custody/visitation orders on those grounds. The opinion mentions stability in the context of respecting an existing residential arrangement and the mother’s relocation decision, not commuting-related exhaustion or educational impact as a basis for modification.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...')."

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 743 (2016)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that parenting schedules must be adapted to reflect the realities of distance and travel time.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.case_name: Bank of America, N.A. v. Prestige Imports, Inc.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser is not about parenting schedules, custody, or family law; it concerns an attorney’s lien and whether a lawyer who withdrew from a contingent fee case without client consent forfeited his right to fees. The court’s analysis focuses on quantum meruit, good cause for withdrawal, and breakdown of the attorney-client relationship. It does not address distance, travel time, or parenting schedules, so it cannot support the stated proposition about Massachusetts courts’ treatment of parenting schedules.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 89 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “From the . . . appearance in any proceeding . . . , the attorney who appears for a client in such proceeding shall have a lien for his reasonable fees and expenses upon his client’s cause of action, counterclaim or claim, upon the judgment... in his client’s favor entered or made in such proceeding, and upon the proceeds derived therefrom.” G. L. c. 221, § 50… However, ‘“an attorney must establish a substantive contractual or quantum meruit basis to recover fees from the client as a prerequisite to filing a lien [under G. L. c. 221, § 50].”’

Anderson v. McWalter, 950 N.E.2d 1105 (M.raw_text: Anderson v. McWalter, 950 N.E.2d 1105 (Mass. App. Ct. 2011)
Anderson v. McWalter, 950 N.E.2d 1105 (M.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that parenting schedules must be adapted to reflect the realities of distance and travel time.
Anderson v. McWalter, 950 N.E.2d 1105 (M.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Anderson v. McWalter from Massachusetts; it is Speed District 802 v. Warning, an Illinois Supreme Court labor/employment case. It concerns unfair labor practices and union representation rights in teacher remediation meetings, not parenting schedules, distance, or travel time in custody or family law matters. Therefore, it does not address, much less support, the proposition about Massachusetts courts adapting parenting schedules to travel realities.
Anderson v. McWalter, 950 N.E.2d 1105 (M.relevant_excerpt: Because the entire opinion concerns Illinois educational labor law and teacher remediation, there is no passage discussing parenting schedules, distance, or travel time; thus, no relevant excerpt can be provided.

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Additionally, Massachusetts public policy promotes the stability and wellbeing of children, which includes minimizing unnecessary disruption to their schooling.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly recognizes stability as an important component of a child’s best interests in the removal analysis. In remanding for a new evidentiary hearing, the court directs that “stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child” and warns against “unnecessary tampering with the status quo,” which necessarily includes disruption such as moving and changing schools. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts public policy favors stability and minimizing unnecessary disruption to children’s lives, including their schooling.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In light of the fact that more than three years have passed since the judgment was entered and the mother and the child relocated to Illinois, we conclude that a further evidentiary hearing is required… In determining the best interests of the child, weight, of course, should be given to the fact that ‘[stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003).”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Additionally, Massachusetts public policy promotes the stability and wellbeing of children, which includes minimizing unnecessary disruption to their schooling.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion does not explicitly articulate a broad public policy about minimizing school disruption, but it does ground its custody analysis in the overarching Massachusetts principle that the "best interests" and welfare of the children are paramount. In applying that standard, the court notes that the custodial arrangement should "minimize[] disruption" and "foster[] a healthy environment" for the children's growth and development, which implicitly encompasses stability in their day-to-day life, consistent with the cited proposition. However, the case is more about general best-interests custody principles than a focused statement on schooling disruption specifically.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.
